awd_titl_txt: Genomics of Diseases in Wildlife Workshop; Colorado State University; June 3-9, 2018
awd_abstract_narration:
The award provides funding for graduate students to participate in a Genomics of Diseases in Wildlife workshop. The workshop represents an important training and collaborative research experience focused on developing tools for the analysis of genetic sequence data to address problems in wildlife disease ecology and evolution.  This experience provides hands on training to students and scientists through hands on exercises focused around a collaborative project in infectious wildlife disease. The tools participants learn will enable future research that capitalizes on the growing availability of genetic data.  The workshop targets early and mid-career professionals with expertise in four major scientific disciplines to examine host-pathogen interactions in wildlife: genome sciences; wildlife biology; veterinary sciences; and wildlife management and conservation. Workshop organizers are focusing particular attention on assembling a diverse set of participants, with approximately equal gender balance, and attention to ethnic as well as regional diversity. 

Participants in this Genomics of Diseases in Wildlife will be taken from start to finish in the process of using next generation genomic sequence data to address questions in the ecology and evolution of infectious diseases of wildlife. The workshop will address which sequence data are appropriate to address what questions in the area of ecology and evolution of infectious disease. Participants will learn to assess sequence read quality and coverage, map reads to a reference genome, perform de novo assembly of host and pathogen genomes, and annotate assembled genomes. From there, they will assess read quality, create alignments for comparative analyses within and among hosts and pathogens. Several forms of analysis will be included with a focus on comparative genomics across space and time, including the patterns of evolution associated with disease outbreaks.  All of these activities will focus on recently available sequence related to a current problem in wildlife disease ecology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In June 2018, we held a weeklong workshop to provide training in applying genomic techniques to the study and management of wildlife diseases (GDW2018). The workshop included instruction from experts in the field, applied computer labs using real-world data, and plenary talks from scientists using genomic techniques to study wildlife diseases. An important aspect of the workshop is that it also allowed for networking and connecting wildlife researchers from different disciplines and stages of their career. Demographic diversity is essential to GDW with GDW2017/2018 with women representing over 50% of the participants, organizers, and guest speakers. The participants represented a blend of researchers from academia, government, and nonprofit institutions from across the USA.  Additionally, ~25% of the attendees were from outside the US, including participants from developing countries seeking solutions for wildlife disease management. Nearly a quarter of participants were from under-represented backgrounds. These are indicators of the expanding relevance of the GDW workshops to potentially ameliorate the impact of disease in wildlife on a national and international scale. 

The first two GDW workshops offered in June 2017 and 2018 trained 44 participants and were very highly ranked in post-workshop surveys (4.5 and 4.8 out of 5 in 2017 and 2018, respectively). Paramount to the goals of the workshop, and validated by the participant surveys, the content of GDW is continuously updated by the latest technologies and/or insights only possible through the study of DNA variation of host and pathogen. The design of the workshop fosters discussion among instructors and participants alike, to form a collaborative ‘think tank’ addressing current issues and scientific breakthroughs. This has resulted in the May 2019 publication in the Journal of Heredity of a horizon scan study, co-authored by all participants of GDW2017, that identifies the most pressing needs for genomic studies in wildlife disease. Further, continued communication between attendees, instructors and invited speakers is ongoing, facilitated by online forums such as GDW Google Group, that expands with each year’s participants.
